subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Quickscript for American English
msgSnippet: Chuck: I agree with you regarding letting accent come through in the spelling. I do not see that it is a big problem if people spell words according to their
messageBody:
Chuck:

I agree with you regarding letting accent come through in the spelling.
I do not see that it is a big problem if people spell words according to
their pronunciation of those words. The alternative would be to impose
an external standard for spelling. In other words, one would have to
convince people to accept and use a pronunciation other than their own
to determine how words should be spelt. Of course, despite the alleged
"good intentions" of the group attempting to impose the "standard,"
those asked to spell with someone else's pronunciation will probably
inevitably believe their own dialect is considered inferior to the
"standard" as they are instructed not to use it. The result would
probably be that they would resist using the new alphabet.

The second and more serious problem is that if one has to learn an
artificial standard, then that defeats, at least to some extent, the
whole purpose of alphabet reform. I believe it is fair to say most of
the people on the Shavian group have concluded that a "standard" is
necessary although some believe a British version and an American
version would probably be advantageous. This would reduce the level of
phonicity (1 to 1 correspondence between speech and spelling) of QS.

In my opinion, accepting this argument puts us back, at least to some
extent, into the situation we are in now in which words are spelt in
ways which the individual's pronunciation does not match. English
speakers have been stuck with an alphabet that works so poorly for so
long, that when you try to reorganize it, even the people interested in
reform want to return to a system with less phonicity almost immediately
by alleging it is "necessary."

But what is necessary is communication. The only reason to be concerned
whether there is a "standard" spelling is if it negatively affects
communication. I do not believe it will prevent people from deciphering
words written in QS since language is full of redundancies. Nor do I
believe it will even slow a person's reading speed appreciably once they
have attained QS fluency.

For beginners using junior QS, we could develop a system to mark the
vowel of the accented syllable. This might be useful initially.

Your comment regarding "those who would want to note any shortness" was
obscure to me. The "hot" vowel is short. The longer vowel in brit-speak
"father" I seldom use. Why would there be a need to represent "shortness"?

Paige Gabhart


Chuck Peck wrote:

>This is an interesting discussion. I’ve seen writing
>systems that have notation for emphasis/weight/accent.
>
>
>I personally do not hear or say any difference between
>"father", "bother”, "hot" or "cot." But for those who
>would want to note any Shortness maybe there could be
>some additional notation setup. I use character #32
>for this sound.
>
>I also use character #33 for the "caught" or "awe"
>words.
>
>One thing I think that should be kept in mind is that
>this is a Phonic writing system. So maybe each person
>should let their accent come through in their writing.
>I write snail-mail (regular postal mail) with several
>other Quickscript users. I always find it interesting
>to hear their accent reflected in their writing. Not
>just a British / American difference but also just
>from across the country.
>
>--- "C. Paige Gabhart" <pgabhart@...> wrote:
>
>
>>kyudosha:
>>
>>There are a number of dialectical differences
>>between Received
>>pronunciation (British English) and American
>>English, just as there are
>>dialectical differences across America.
>>
>>No. 30 is used for the initial vowel sound in
>>"Andy."
>>No. 31 is used for what we called in school the
>>"long i" sound.
>>No. 32 is similar to No. 34, but represents a longer
>>vowel sound. Think
>>of a Brit dragging out the initial vowel as they say
>>"father". If you
>>pronounce "father" like "bother," you probably don't
>>need No. 32.
>>No. 34 is a shorter sound as in "hot" or "cot."
>>I use No. 33 for the vowel sound in "caught" or
>>"awe" although there is
>>a vowel shift still underway in America which
>>combines "caught" and
>>"cot" so that they sound the same. To those who
>>still make the
>>distinction, it sound very peculiar to hear someone
>>speaking who does
>>not make it.
>>
>>Paige Gabhart
>>
>>
>>
>
>
>
>
>

I agree with you regarding letting accent come through in the spelling.
